
# install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("tm012/likertSim")

library(likertSim)

# minimal example (first column must be coder_id)
df_real <- data.frame(
  coder_id = paste0("r", 1:50),
  A = sample(1:5, 50, TRUE),
  B = sample(1:5, 50, TRUE),
  C = sample(1:5, 50, TRUE)
)

out <- simulate_and_compare(
  df_real,
  K_min = 1, K_max = 5,
  N_sim = 200,
  noise_factor = 1.2,
  bias = 0.2,
  corr_alpha = 0.3,
  mode = "threshold"
)

head(out$comparison)
out$warnings


| Tier         | noise\_factor | bias | corr\_alpha | What it means in practice (5-point scale)                                                                               |
| ------------ | ------------- | ---- | ----------- | ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Baseline** | 1.00          | 0.00 | 0.00        | Raters use scale as in real data; no change.                                                                            |
| **Mild**     | 1.05          | 0.10 | 0.10        | Slightly more scattered (SD +5%), \~⅒ of a category higher; inter-item r shrinks 10%.                                   |
| **Moderate** | 1.15          | 0.25 | 0.25        | SD +15% (variance +32%), about ¼ category leniency; correlations ×0.75 (α/ICC start to drop).                           |
| **Strong**   | 1.30          | 0.40 | 0.50        | SD +30% (variance +69%), almost ½ category shift up; correlations halved (α/ICC fall substantially).                    |
| **Extreme**  | 1.60          | 0.60 | 0.80        | Very noisy (SD +60%, variance +156%), \~⅗ category bias; correlations cut to 20% of original (structure near collapse). |


| Tier         | noise\_factor | bias | corr\_alpha | What it means in practice (7-point scale)                                                                                 |
| ------------ | ------------- | ---- | ----------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- |
| **Baseline** | 1.00          | 0.00 | 0.00        | Pure mimic of real raters.                                                                                                |
| **Mild**     | 1.05          | 0.10 | 0.10        | SD +5%; \~⅒ category shift (hardly noticeable); correlations ×0.9.                                                        |
| **Moderate** | 1.15          | 0.25 | 0.25        | SD +15% (variance +32%); about ¼ category bias (detectable leniency/severity); correlations ×0.75.                        |
| **Strong**   | 1.30          | 0.40 | 0.50        | SD +30% (variance +69%); \~0.4 category shift (between “Agree” and “Strongly Agree”); correlations halved.                |
| **Extreme**  | 1.60          | 0.60 | 0.80        | SD +60% (variance +156%); \~0.6 category shift; inter-item correlations reduced to 20% (construct reliability collapses). |


noise_factor (scales SD) → must be ≥ 0.

Typical use: ≥ 1.0 to add noise (1.05, 1.15, 1.30…).

You may use 0.8–1.0 to model less noisy/very consistent raters.

Never negative (a negative SD multiplier is meaningless).

bias (in “category units”) → can be positive or negative.

+ bias = lenient (pushes scores up).

– bias = severe (pushes scores down).

Safe range: ≈ −0.6 to +0.6 (bigger shifts risk floor/ceiling on 5–7 pt scales).

corr_alpha (correlation shrink toward zero) → use 0–1 only.

0 = keep correlations; 1 = wipe structure (identity).

Do not use negative (that would “anti-shrink” and can break the correlation matrix).

Practical range: 0.00, 0.10, 0.25, 0.50, 0.80 (your tiers).
